refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GtkPrintOperation is the high-level, portable printing API. It looks a bit different than other GTK+ dialogs such as the GtkFileChooser, since some platforms don't expose enough infrastructure to implement a good print dialog. On such platforms, GtkPrintOperation uses the native print dialog. On platforms which do not provide a native print dialog, GTK+ uses its own, see GtkPrintUnixDialog.

The typical way to use the high-level printing API is to create a GtkPrintOperation object with gtk_print_operation_new() when the user selects to print. Then you set some properties on it, e.g. the page size, any GtkPrintSettings from previous print operations, the number of pages, the current page, etc.

Then you start the print operation by calling gtk_print_operation_run(). It will then show a dialog, let the user select a printer and options. When the user finished the dialog various signals will be emitted on the GtkPrintOperation, the main one being ::draw-page, which you are supposed to catch and render the page on the provided GtkPrintContext using Cairo.

example.title: The high-level printing API

refsect1.para: By default GtkPrintOperation uses an external application to do print preview. To implement a custom print preview, an application must connect to the preview signal. The functions gtk_print_operation_print_preview_render_page(), gtk_print_operation_preview_end_preview() and gtk_print_operation_preview_is_selected() are useful when implementing a print preview.
Printing support was added in GTK+ 2.10.

refsect2.title: enum GtkPrintStatus
refsect2.programlisting: typedef enum { GTK_PRINT_STATUS_INITIAL, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PREPARING, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_GENERATING_DATA, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_SENDING_DATA, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PENDING, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PENDING_ISSUE, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_PRINTING, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_FINISHED, GTK_PRINT_STATUS_FINISHED_ABORTED } GtkPrintStatus;
refsect2.para: The status gives a rough indication of the completion of a running print operation.

listitem.simpara: The printing has not started yet; this status is set initially, and while the print dialog is shown.
This status is set while the begin-print signal is emitted and during pagination.
This status is set while the pages are being rendered.
The print job is being sent off to the printer.
The print job has been sent to the printer, but is not printed for some reason, e.g. the printer may be stopped.
Some problem has occurred during printing, e.g. a paper jam.
The printer is processing the print job.
The printing has been completed successfully.
The printing has been aborted.

refsect2.title: enum GtkPrintOperationAction
refsect2.para: The action parameter to gtk_print_operation_run() determines what action the print operation should perform.

listitem.simpara: Show the print dialog.
Start to print without showing the print dialog, based on the current print settings.
Show the print preview.
Export to a file. This requires the export-filename property to be set.

refsect2.title: enum GtkPrintOperationResult
refsect2.para: A value of this type is returned by gtk_print_operation_run().

listitem.simpara: An error has occured.
The print settings should be stored.
The print operation has been canceled, the print settings should not be stored.
The print operation is not complete yet. This value will only be returned when running asynchronously.

refsect2.title: enum GtkPrintError
refsect2.para: Error codes that identify various errors that can occur while using the GTK+ printing support.

listitem.simpara: An unspecified error occurred.
An internal error occurred.
A memory allocation failed.
An error occurred while loading a page setup or paper size from a key file.

refsect2.title: GTK_PRINT_ERROR
refsect2.para: The GQuark used for GtkPrintError errors.

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GtkPrintOperation.

listitem.simpara: a new GtkPrintOperation

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_allow_async ()
refsect2.para: Sets whether the gtk_print_operation_run() may return before the print operation is completed. Note that some platforms may not allow asynchronous operation.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
TRUE to allow asynchronous operation

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_get_error ()
refsect2.para: Call this when the result of a print operation is GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_ERROR, either as returned by gtk_print_operation_run(), or in the "done" signal handler. The returned GError will contain more details on what went wrong.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
return location for the error

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_default_page_setup ()
refsect2.para: Makes default_page_setup the default page setup for op.
This page setup will be used by gtk_print_operation_run(), but it can be overridden on a per-page basis by connecting to the "request-page-setup" signal.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
a GtkPageSetup, or NULL

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_get_default_page_setup ()
refsect2.para: Returns the default page setup, see gtk_print_operation_set_default_page_setup().

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the default page setup

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_print_settings ()
refsect2.para: Sets the print settings for op. This is typically used to re-establish print settings from a previous print operation, see gtk_print_operation_run().

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
GtkPrintSettings, or NULL

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_get_print_settings ()
refsect2.para: Returns the current print settings.
Note that the return value is NULL until either gtk_print_operation_set_print_settings() or gtk_print_operation_run() have been called.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the current print settings of op.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_job_name ()
refsect2.para: Sets the name of the print job. The name is used to identify the job (e.g. in monitoring applications like eggcups).
If you don't set a job name, GTK+ picks a default one by numbering successive print jobs.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
a string that identifies the print job

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_n_pages ()
refsect2.para: Sets the number of pages in the document.
This must be set to a positive number before the rendering starts. It may be set in a "begin-print" signal hander.

Note that the page numbers passed to the "request-page-setup" and "draw-page" signals are 0-based, i.e. if the user chooses to print all pages, the last ::draw-page signal will be for page n_pages - 1.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the number of pages

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_current_page ()
refsect2.para: Sets the current page.
If this is called before gtk_print_operation_run(), the user will be able to select to print only the current page.
Note that this only makes sense for pre-paginated documents.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the current page, 0-based

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_use_full_page ()
refsect2.para: If full_page is TRUE, the transformation for the cairo context obtained from GtkPrintContext puts the origin at the top left corner of the page (which may not be the top left corner of the sheet, depending on page orientation and the number of pages per sheet). Otherwise, the origin is at the top left corner of the imageable area (i.e. inside the margins).

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
TRUE to set up the GtkPrintContext for the full page

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_unit ()
refsect2.para: Sets up the transformation for the cairo context obtained from GtkPrintContext in such a way that distances are measured in units of unit.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the unit to use

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_export_filename ()
refsect2.para: Sets up the GtkPrintOperation to generate a file instead of showing the print dialog. The indended use of this function is for implementing "Export to PDF" actions. Currently, PDF is the only supported format.
"Print to PDF" support is independent of this and is done by letting the user pick the "Print to PDF" item from the list of printers in the print dialog.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the filename for the exported file

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_show_progress ()
refsect2.para: If show_progress is TRUE, the print operation will show a progress dialog during the print operation.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
TRUE to show a progress dialog

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_track_print_status ()
refsect2.para: If track_status is TRUE, the print operation will try to continue report on the status of the print job in the printer queues and printer. This can allow your application to show things like "out of paper" issues, and when the print job actually reaches the printer.
This function is often implemented using some form of polling, so it should not be enabled unless needed.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
TRUE to track status after printing

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_custom_tab_label ()
refsect2.para: Sets the label for the tab holding custom widgets.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the label to use, or NULL to use the default label

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_run ()
refsect2.programlisting: GtkPrintOperationResult gtk_print_operation_run (GtkPrintOperation *op, GtkPrintOperationAction action, GtkWindow *parent, GError **error);
refsect2.para: Runs the print operation, by first letting the user modify print settings in the print dialog, and then print the document.

Normally that this function does not return until the rendering of all pages is complete. You can connect to the "status-changed" signal on op to obtain some information about the progress of the print operation. Furthermore, it may use a recursive mainloop to show the print dialog.
Note that gtk_print_operation_run() can only be called once on a given GtkPrintOperation.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the action to start
Transient parent of the dialog, or NULL
Return location for errors, or NULL

the result of the print operation. A return value of GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_APPLY indicates that the printing was completed successfully. In this case, it is a good idea to obtain the used print settings with gtk_print_operation_get_print_settings() and store them for reuse with the next print operation. A value of GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_IN_PROGRESS means the operation is running asynchronously, and will emit the "done" signal when done.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_cancel ()
refsect2.para: Cancels a running print operation. This function may be called from a "begin-print", "paginate" or "draw-page" signal handler to stop the currently running print operation.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_draw_page_finish ()
refsect2.para: Signalize that drawing of particular page is complete.

It is called after completion of page drawing (e.g. drawing in another thread). If gtk_print_operation_set_defer_drawing() was called before, then this function has to be called by application. In another case it is called by the library itself.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation

refsect2.para: Since 2.16

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_set_defer_drawing ()
refsect2.para: Sets up the GtkPrintOperation to wait for calling of gtk_print_operation_draw_page_finish() from application. It can be used for drawing page in another thread.
This function must be called in the callback of "draw-page" signal.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation

refsect2.para: Since 2.16

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_get_status ()
refsect2.para: Returns the status of the print operation. Also see gtk_print_operation_get_status_string().

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
the status of the print operation

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_get_status_string ()
refsect2.para: Returns a string representation of the status of the print operation. The string is translated and suitable for displaying the print status e.g. in a GtkStatusbar.
Use gtk_print_operation_get_status() to obtain a status value that is suitable for programmatic use.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
a string representation of the status of the print operation

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_is_finished ()
refsect2.para: A convenience function to find out if the print operation is finished, either successfully (GTK_PRINT_STATUS_FINISHED) or unsuccessfully (GTK_PRINT_STATUS_FINISHED_ABORTED).

Note: when you enable print status tracking the print operation can be in a non-finished state even after done has been called, as the operation status then tracks the print job status on the printer.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperation
TRUE, if the print operation is finished.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog ()
refsect2.para: Runs a page setup dialog, letting the user modify the values from page_setup. If the user cancels the dialog, the returned GtkPageSetup is identical to the passed in page_setup, otherwise it contains the modifications done in the dialog.
Note that this function may use a recursive mainloop to show the page setup dialog. See gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog_async() if this is a problem.

listitem.simpara: transient parent, or NULL
an existing GtkPageSetup, or NULL
a GtkPrintSettings
a new GtkPageSetup

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: GtkPageSetupDoneFunc ()
refsect2.para: The type of function that is passed to gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog_async(). This function will be called when the page setup dialog is dismissed, and also serves as destroy notify for data.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPageSetup that has been
user data that has been passed to gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog_async().

refsect2.title: gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog_async ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog_async (GtkWindow *parent, GtkPageSetup *page_setup, GtkPrintSettings *settings, GtkPageSetupDoneFunc done_cb, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: Runs a page setup dialog, letting the user modify the values from page_setup.

In contrast to gtk_print_run_page_setup_dialog(), this function returns after showing the page setup dialog on platforms that support this, and calls done_cb from a signal handler for the ::response signal of the dialog.

listitem.simpara: transient parent, or NULL
an existing GtkPageSetup, or NULL
a GtkPrintSettings
a function to call when the user saves the modified page setup
user data to pass to done_cb

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_preview_end_preview ()
refsect2.para: Ends a preview.
This function must be called to finish a custom print preview.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperationPreview

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_preview_is_selected ()
refsect2.para: Returns whether the given page is included in the set of pages that have been selected for printing.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperationPreview
a page number
TRUE if the page has been selected for printing

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: gtk_print_operation_preview_render_page ()
refsect2.para: Renders a page to the preview, using the print context that was passed to the "preview" handler together with preview.
A custom iprint preview should use this function in its ::expose handler to render the currently selected page.
Note that this function requires a suitable cairo context to be associated with the print context.

listitem.simpara: a GtkPrintOperationPreview
the page to render

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "allow-async" property
refsect2.para: Determines whether the print operation may run asynchronously or not.
Some systems don't support asynchronous printing, but those that do will return GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_IN_PROGRESS as the status, and emit the "done" signal when the operation is actually done.

The Windows port does not support asynchronous operation at all (this is unlikely to change). On other platforms, all actions except for GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_ACTION_EXPORT support asynchronous operation.
Default value: FALSE
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "current-page" property
refsect2.para: The current page in the document.
If this is set before gtk_print_operation_run(), the user will be able to select to print only the current page.
Note that this only makes sense for pre-paginated documents.
Allowed values: >= G_MAXULONG
Default value: -1
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "custom-tab-label" property
refsect2.para: Used as the label of the tab containing custom widgets. Note that this property may be ignored on some platforms.
If this is NULL, GTK+ uses a default label.
Default value: NULL
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "default-page-setup" property
refsect2.para: The GtkPageSetup used by default.
This page setup will be used by gtk_print_operation_run(), but it can be overridden on a per-page basis by connecting to the "request-page-setup" signal.
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "export-filename" property
refsect2.para: The name of a file to generate instead of showing the print dialog. Currently, PDF is the only supported format.
The intended use of this property is for implementing "Export to PDF" actions.
"Print to PDF" support is independent of this and is done by letting the user pick the "Print to PDF" item from the list of printers in the print dialog.
Default value: NULL
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "job-name" property
refsect2.para: A string used to identify the job (e.g. in monitoring applications like eggcups).
If you don't set a job name, GTK+ picks a default one by numbering successive print jobs.
Default value: ""
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "n-pages" property
refsect2.para: The number of pages in the document.
This must be set to a positive number before the rendering starts. It may be set in a "begin-print" signal hander.

Note that the page numbers passed to the "request-page-setup" and "draw-page" signals are 0-based, i.e. if the user chooses to print all pages, the last ::draw-page signal will be for page n_pages - 1.
Allowed values: >= G_MAXULONG
Default value: -1
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "print-settings" property
refsect2.para: The GtkPrintSettings used for initializing the dialog.
Setting this property is typically used to re-establish print settings from a previous print operation, see gtk_print_operation_run().
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "show-progress" property
refsect2.para: Determines whether to show a progress dialog during the print operation.
Default value: FALSE
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "status" property
refsect2.para: The status of the print operation.
Default value: GTK_PRINT_STATUS_INITIAL
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "status-string" property
refsect2.para: A string representation of the status of the print operation. The string is translated and suitable for displaying the print status e.g. in a GtkStatusbar.
See the "status" property for a status value that is suitable for programmatic use.
Default value: ""
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "track-print-status" property
refsect2.para: If TRUE, the print operation will try to continue report on the status of the print job in the printer queues and printer. This can allow your application to show things like "out of paper" issues, and when the print job actually reaches the printer. However, this is often implemented using polling, and should not be enabled unless needed.
Default value: FALSE
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "unit" property
refsect2.para: The transformation for the cairo context obtained from GtkPrintContext is set up in such a way that distances are measured in units of unit.
Default value: GTK_UNIT_PIXEL
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "use-full-page" property
refsect2.para: If TRUE, the transformation for the cairo context obtained from GtkPrintContext puts the origin at the top left corner of the page (which may not be the top left corner of the sheet, depending on page orientation and the number of pages per sheet). Otherwise, the origin is at the top left corner of the imageable area (i.e. inside the margins).
Default value: FALSE
Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "begin-print" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkPrintContext *context, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted after the user has finished changing print settings in the dialog, before the actual rendering starts.
A typical use for ::begin-print is to use the parameters from the GtkPrintContext and paginate the document accordingly, and then set the number of pages with gtk_print_operation_set_n_pages().

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the GtkPrintContext for the current operation
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "create-custom-widget" signal
refsect2.programlisting: GObject* user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted when displaying the print dialog. If you return a widget in a handler for this signal it will be added to a custom tab in the print dialog. You typically return a container widget with multiple widgets in it.

The print dialog owns the returned widget, and its lifetime is not controlled by the application. However, the widget is guaranteed to stay around until the "custom-widget-apply" signal is emitted on the operation. Then you can read out any information you need from the widgets.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
A custom widget that gets embedded in the print dialog, or NULL

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "custom-widget-apply" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkWidget *widget, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted right before "begin-print" if you added a custom widget in the "";create-custom-widget handler. When you get this signal you should read the information from the custom widgets, as the widgets are not guaraneed to be around at a later time.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the custom widget added in create-custom-widget
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "done" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkPrintOperationResult result, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted when the print operation run has finished doing everything required for printing.
result gives you information about what happened during the run. If result is GTK_PRINT_OPERATION_RESULT_ERROR then you can call gtk_print_operation_get_error() for more information.
If you enabled print status tracking then gtk_print_operation_is_finished() may still return FALSE after "done" was emitted.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the result of the print operation
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "draw-page" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkPrintContext *context, gint page_nr, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Use gtk_print_operation_set_use_full_page() and gtk_print_operation_set_unit() before starting the print operation to set up the transformation of the cairo context according to your needs.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the GtkPrintContext for the current operation
the number of the currently printed page (0-based)
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "end-print" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkPrintContext *context, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted after all pages have been rendered. A handler for this signal can clean up any resources that have been allocated in the "begin-print" handler.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the GtkPrintContext for the current operation
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "paginate" signal
refsect2.programlisting: gboolean user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkPrintContext *context, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted after the "begin-print" signal, but before the actual rendering starts. It keeps getting emitted until a connected signal handler returns TRUE.

The ::paginate signal is intended to be used for paginating a document in small chunks, to avoid blocking the user interface for a long time. The signal handler should update the number of pages using gtk_print_operation_set_n_pages(), and return TRUE if the document has been completely paginated.
If you don't need to do pagination in chunks, you can simply do it all in the ::begin-print handler, and set the number of pages from there.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the GtkPrintContext for the current operation
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
TRUE if pagination is complete

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "preview" signal
refsect2.programlisting: gboolean user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, GtkPrintOperationPreview *preview, GtkPrintContext *context, GtkWindow *parent, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Gets emitted when a preview is requested from the native dialog.
The default handler for this signal uses an external viewer application to preview.

To implement a custom print preview, an application must return TRUE from its handler for this signal. In order to use the provided context for the preview implementation, it must be given a suitable cairo context with gtk_print_context_set_cairo_context().

The custom preview implementation can use gtk_print_operation_preview_is_selected() and gtk_print_operation_preview_render_page() to find pages which are selected for print and render them. The preview must be finished by calling gtk_print_operation_preview_end_preview() (typically in response to the user clicking a close button).

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the GtkPrintPreviewOperation for the current operation
the GtkPrintContext that will be used
the GtkWindow to use as window parent, or NULL
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
TRUE if the listener wants to take over control of the preview

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
the GtkPrintContext for the current operation
the number of the currently printed page (0-based)
the GtkPageSetup
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "status-changed" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperation *operation, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Emitted at between the various phases of the print operation. See GtkPrintStatus for the phases that are being discriminated. Use gtk_print_operation_get_status() to find out the current status.

listitem.simpara: the GtkPrintOperation on which the signal was emitted
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Since 2.10

refsect2.title: The "got-page-size" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperationPreview *preview, GtkPrintContext *context, GtkPageSetup *page_setup, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: The ::got-page-size signal is emitted once for each page that gets rendered to the preview.
A handler for this signal should update the context according to page_setup and set up a suitable cairo context, using gtk_print_context_set_cairo_context().

listitem.simpara: the object on which the signal is emitted
the current GtkPrintContext
the GtkPageSetup for the current page
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.title: The "ready" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkPrintOperationPreview *preview, GtkPrintContext *context, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: The ::ready signal gets emitted once per preview operation, before the first page is rendered.
A handler for this signal can be used for setup tasks.

listitem.simpara: the object on which the signal is emitted
the current GtkPrintContext
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
